message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Can Generative AI improve social science?
Paper Abstract: Generative AI that can produce realistic text, images, and other human-like outputs is currently transforming many different industries. Yet it is not yet known how such tools might influence social science research. I argue Generative AI has the potential to improve survey research, online experiments, automated content analyses, agent-based models, and other techniques commonly used to study human behavior. In the second section of this article, I discuss the many limitations of Generative AI. I examine how bias in the data used to train these tools can negatively impact social science research—as well as a range of other challenges related to ethics, replication, environmental impact, and the proliferation of low-quality research. I conclude by arguing that social scientists can address many of these limitations by creating open-source infrastructure for research on human behavior. Such infrastructure is not only necessary to ensure broad access to high-quality research tools, I argue, but also because the progress of AI will require deeper understanding of the social forces that guide human behavior.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Bias statistics"

Links: [{"title":"Bias (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bias of an estimator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias_of_an_estimator"},{"title":"Talk:Bias (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Bias_(statistics)"},{"title":"Sampling bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_bias"},{"title":"Matching (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matching_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bootstrapping (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(statistics)"},{"title":"Selection bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_bias"},{"title":"Consistent estimator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistent_estimator"},{"title":"Simpson's paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simpson's_paradox"},{"title":"Convenience sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convenience_sampling"}]

## Bias in Statistics

Here's a comprehensive overview of bias in statistics based on the search results:

### Definition and Basic Concept

The bias of an estimator is the difference between an estimator's expected value and the true value of the parameter being estimated. In a broader sense, in the field of statistics, bias is a systematic tendency in which the methods used to gather data and estimate a sample statistic present an inaccurate, skewed or distorted (biased) depiction of reality.

### Sources of Bias

Statistical bias exists in numerous stages of the data collection and analysis process, including: the source of the data, the methods used to collect the data, the estimator chosen, and the methods used to analyze the data.

Key types of bias include:

- **Sampling Bias**: In statistics, sampling bias is a bias in which a sample is collected in such a way that some members of the intended population have a lower or higher sampling probability than others.

- **Selection Bias**: Selection bias is the bias introduced by the selection of individuals, groups, or data for analysis in such a way that the association between exposure and outcome among those selected for analysis differs from the association among those eligible.

### Practical Importance

Statistical bias can have significant real world implications as data is used to inform decision making across a wide variety of processes in society. Data is used to inform lawmaking, industry regulation, corporate marketing and distribution tactics, and institutional policies in organizations and workplaces. Therefore, there can be significant implications if statistical bias is not accounted for and controlled.

I've completed a web search for "Survey research methodology." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Survey Research

A survey consists of a predetermined set of questions that is given to a sample. With a representative sample, one can describe the attitudes of the population from which the sample was drawn.(no content)Survey research is often used to assess thoughts, opinions and feelings.

## Survey Design Types

The three general types of survey designs are cross-sectional, successive independent samples, and longitudinal studies. In cross-sectional studies, a sample (or samples) is drawn from the relevant population and studied once.(no content)A successive independent samples design draws multiple random samples from a population at one or more times. This design can study changes within a population, but not changes within individuals because the same individuals are not surveyed more than once.

## Data Collection Methods

Surveys may be conducted by phone, mail, via the internet, and also in person in public spaces.(no content)Questionnaires are the most commonly used tool in survey research.

## Key Methodological Considerations

A good sample selection is key as it allows one to generalize the findings from the sample to the population, which is the whole purpose of survey research.(no content)In addition to this, it is important to ensure that survey questions are not biased such as using suggestive words. This prevents inaccurate results in a survey.

Links: [{"title":"Randomized controlled trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial"},{"title":"Randomized experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_experiment"},{"title":"Cluster-randomised controlled trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster-randomised_controlled_trial"},{"title":"Crossover study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crossover_study"},{"title":"N-of-1 trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N_of_1_trial"},{"title":"Stepped-wedge trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stepped-wedge_trial"},{"title":"Pragmatic clinical trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatic_clinical_trial"},{"title":"Observational study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observational_study"},{"title":"Placebo-controlled study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Placebo-controlled_study"},{"title":"Random assignment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_assignment"}]

## Randomized Controlled Trial Experiment

Here's an overview of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is a type of scientific experiment designed to evaluate the efficacy or safety of an intervention by minimizing bias through the random allocation of participants to one or more comparison groups.

### Key Design Elements

**Random Allocation:** The randomness in the assignment of participants to treatments reduces selection bias and allocation bias, balancing both known and unknown prognostic factors.

**Blinding and Control Groups:** An RCT in clinical research typically compares a proposed new treatment against an existing standard of care; these are then termed the 'experimental' and 'control' treatments, respectively.(no content)When no such generally accepted treatment is available, a placebo may be used in the control group so that participants are blinded, or not given information, about their treatment allocations.

### Gold Standard Status

A well-blinded RCT is considered the gold standard for clinical trials.

### Applications

RCTs are employed in clinical research and also in other research areas, including many of the social sciences.

### Historical Context

The first published Randomized Controlled Trial in medicine appeared in the 1948 paper entitled "Streptomycin treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis", with Austin Bradford Hill credited as having conceived the modern RCT.

## Randomized Controlled Trial Experiment

Here's an overview of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is a type of scientific experiment designed to evaluate the efficacy or safety of an intervention by minimizing bias through the random allocation of participants to one or more comparison groups.

### Key Design Elements

**Random Allocation:** The randomness in the assignment of participants to treatments reduces selection bias and allocation bias, balancing both known and unknown prognostic factors.

**Blinding and Control Groups:** An RCT in clinical research typically compares a proposed new treatment against an existing standard of care; these are then termed the 'experimental' and 'control' treatments, respectively.(no content)When no such generally accepted treatment is available, a placebo may be used in the control group so that participants are blinded, or not given information, about their treatment allocations.

### Gold Standard Status

A well-blinded RCT is considered the gold standard for clinical trials.

### Applications

RCTs are employed in clinical research and also in other research areas, including many of the social sciences.

### Historical Context

The first published Randomized Controlled Trial in medicine appeared in the 1948 paper entitled "Streptomycin treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis", with Austin Bradford Hill credited as having conceived the modern RCT.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of open source software:

## Definition

Open-source software (OSS) is computer software that is released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to use, study, change, and distribute the software and its source code to anyone and for any purpose.

## Key Characteristics

Open-source licenses typically require that source code be made available without restrictions on modification or redistribution, and prohibit discrimination against individuals or groups. Under this development model, anyone can obtain, modify, and redistribute open-source code.

## Development Model

Programmers participating in the open-source movement contribute to software development through voluntary collaboration and code sharing.(no content)Modifications are typically shared with the broader community, creating a collaborative development process where contributions are tracked and attributed.

## Related Terms

Free and open-source software (FOSS) is software available under a license that gives users the right to use, share, modify, and distribute the software – modified or not – to everyone and provides the means to exercise those rights using the software's source code.

## Benefits

Reasons for using FOSS include decreased software costs, increased security against malware, stability, privacy, opportunities for educational usage, and giving users more control over their own hardware.

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"Mother agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother_agent"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about agent-based models:

## Definition

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

## How They Work

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.(no content)The process is one of emergence, where "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts" - in other words, higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.(no content)Individual agents are typically characterized as boundedly rational, presumed to be acting in what they perceive as their own interests, such as reproduction, economic benefit, or social status, using heuristics or simple decision-making rules.

## Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

## Applications

Agent-based models are used across multiple disciplines. In an ecological context, agent-based modeling can be used to model the behaviour of different species such as insects infestations, other invasive species, aphids, aquatic populations, and the evolution of innate foraging behaviors.(no content)Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

I've completed the web search for "Generative AI". Here's a comprehensive overview of what I found:

## What is Generative AI?

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## How It Works

These models learn the underlying patterns and structures of their training data to create new content. Large language models are designed to be capable of generating and understanding human language as well as being able to conduct a wide range of tasks by feeding the models an immense amount of data in order to execute accurate responses.

## Applications

Generative AI has been adopted in a variety of sectors, including software development, healthcare, finance, entertainment, customer service, sales and marketing, art, writing, and product design.(no content)Generative AI software examples include ChatGPT, Midjourney, and DALL-E.

## Key Players

Technology companies developing generative AI include Alibaba, Anthropic, Baidu, DeepSeek, Google, Meta AI, Microsoft, Mistral AI, OpenAI, Perplexity AI, xAI, and Yandex.

## Concerns

Generative AI has been used for cybercrime, and to deceive and manipulate people through fake news and deepfakes. Generative AI may lead to mass replacement of human jobs. The tools themselves have been described as violating intellectual property laws, since they are trained on copyrighted works. Many generative AI systems use large-scale data centers whose environmental impacts include e-waste, consumption of fresh water for cooling, and high energy consumption.

These models learn the underlying patterns and structures of their training data to create new content. Large language models are designed to be capable of generating and understanding human language as well as being able to conduct a wide range of tasks by feeding the models an immense amount of data in order to execute accurate responses.

## Applications

Generative AI has been adopted in a variety of sectors, including software development, healthcare, finance, entertainment, customer service, sales and marketing, art, writing, and product design.(no content)Generative AI software examples include ChatGPT, Midjourney, and DALL-E.

## Key Players

Technology companies developing generative AI include Alibaba, Anthropic, Baidu, DeepSeek, Google, Meta AI, Microsoft, Mistral AI, OpenAI, Perplexity AI, xAI, and Yandex.

## Concerns

Generative AI has been used for cybercrime, and to deceive and manipulate people through fake news and deepfakes. Generative AI may lead to mass replacement of human jobs. The tools themselves have been described as violating intellectual property laws, since they are trained on copyrighted works. Many generative AI systems use large-scale data centers whose environmental impacts include e-waste, consumption of fresh water for cooling, and high energy consumption.

Based on the search results, here's what content analysis is:

## Definition

Content analysis is the study of documents and communication artifacts, including texts, photos, speeches, or essays.(no content)Social scientists use content analysis to examine patterns in communication in a replicable and systematic manner.

## Key Characteristics

Content analysis involves systematic reading or observation of texts or artifacts which are assigned labels (sometimes called codes) to indicate the presence of interesting, meaningful pieces of content.(no content)By systematically labeling the content of a set of texts, researchers can analyse patterns of content quantitatively using statistical methods, or use qualitative methods to analyse meanings of content within texts.

## Types of Approaches

Content analysis can take different forms:

- **Quantitative**: Quantitative content analysis highlights frequency counts and statistical analysis of these coded frequencies. Quantitative content analysis begins with a framed hypothesis with coding decided on before the analysis begins.

- **Qualitative**: Qualitative analysis deals with the intricacies of latent interpretations, whereas quantitative has a focus on manifest meanings.

## Advantages and Applications

One of the key advantages of using content analysis to analyse social phenomena is their non-invasive nature, in contrast to simulating social experiences or collecting survey answers.(no content)Computers are increasingly used in content analysis to automate the labeling (or coding) of documents. Simple computational techniques can provide descriptive data such as word frequencies and document lengths.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of "Can Generative AI improve social science?" paper. Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes new applications and approaches for using generative AI in social science research.

**Extracted Triples:** 7 entities were identified and verified:

1. **Generative artificial intelligence** (artifact) - Uses: The core technology discussed for improving social science methods
2. **Survey methodology** (method) - Uses: A research technique that can be enhanced by generative AI
